• No information about required technologies. Does not specify languages, frameworks, tools, or environments.

Job Title: Forward Deployed Engineer

Job Description:
We are looking for a Forward Deployed Engineer who will work directly with customers to design, build, and deliver high‑quality technical solutions. This role blends software engineering, problem solving, and hands‑on collaboration with customer teams. You will help integrate our products into complex environments, ensure successful deployments, and act as a trusted technical advisor throughout the engagement.

Responsibilities:
• Develop, deploy, and maintain production‑grade software solutions tailored to customer needs  
• Work closely with customer stakeholders to understand requirements, workflows, and technical constraints  
• Integrate our products into existing customer systems and infrastructure  
• Investigate and resolve issues across the full technology stack  
• Collaborate with internal engineering and product teams to influence product direction based on real‑world use cases  
• Deliver clear technical guidance, documentation, and support to customer teams  
• Travel to customer sites as needed to ensure smooth implementations and successful outcomes  

Requirements:
• 3 or more years of professional software engineering experience working with production systems  
• Strong programming skills and the ability to design reliable, maintainable solutions  
• Proven ability to diagnose and solve complex technical problems  
• Experience in a customer‑facing technical role, ideally involving systems integration, professional services, or technical consulting  
• Comfort working in fast‑paced, ambiguous environments where requirements evolve  
• Strong communication skills, with the ability to translate technical concepts for both technical and non‑technical audiences  

Preferred Qualifications:
• Experience across multiple parts of the technology stack, such as backend services, APIs, data pipelines, or cloud infrastructure  
• Familiarity with modern development practices, including version control, automated testing, and CI/CD  
• Prior experience working with enterprise customers or large‑scale deployments  

If you are excited about solving real‑world problems, working directly with customers, and deploying software in dynamic environments, we’d love to hear from you.

Location: Remote

Role Title: International Coding Educator

Role Summary  
The International Coding Educator is responsible for delivering high‑quality online programming classes to learners in clearly defined age groups. Instruction will span introductory to intermediate concepts using block‑based and text‑based tools. The educator will guide students in building age‑appropriate projects such as simple apps, games, websites, AI experiments, and beginner robotics activities. The role emphasizes structured, engaging, and inclusive teaching that supports curiosity, creativity, and measurable learning outcomes.

Key Responsibilities  
• Teach assigned age groups (for example: Ages 5–8, 9–12, or 13–18) using curriculum tailored to each developmental level.  
• Deliver live online sessions based on the company’s curriculum and teaching framework.  
• Teach defined subject areas such as introductory programming, web development basics, Python fundamentals, and beginner robotics.  
• Use designated tools and languages such as Scratch, Code.org, HTML/CSS, JavaScript, Python, and introductory robotics platforms.  
• Adapt teaching methods to different learning styles and age‑appropriate pacing.  
• Provide constructive feedback, track student progress, and maintain accurate class records.  
• Communicate effectively with the program director and curriculum team.  
• Support small class sizes by offering guidance, troubleshooting help, and encouragement during sessions.  
• Contribute to an inclusive learning environment that respects diverse backgrounds and accessibility needs.  
• Follow all safety, privacy, and child‑protection guidelines.

Work Schedule and Format  
• Part‑time or contract‑based role, depending on assignment.  
• Weekly teaching hours determined by class volume and time‑zone alignment.  
• Live class sessions typically 45–90 minutes each.  
• Occasional asynchronous tasks such as grading or lesson preparation.

Qualifications  
Required:  
• Experience teaching or tutoring children or teens, preferably in coding or STEM.  
• Proficiency in at least two relevant programming languages or platforms.  
• Strong communication and classroom‑management skills.  
• Reliable computer, webcam, microphone, and high‑speed internet.

Preferred:  
• Formal teaching experience or education‑related training.  
• Certifications in computer science, education, or related fields.  
• Experience teaching online in small‑group environments.  
• Familiarity with additional programming tools or educational platforms.

Compensation  
• Compensation provided on a per‑class or hourly basis, depending on contract terms.  
• Rate range and any additional incentives will be communicated during the hiring process.

Reporting Structure  
• Reports to the Program Director or designated Curriculum Lead.

Training and Onboarding  
• Comprehensive onboarding provided, including platform training, curriculum walkthroughs, and teaching standards.

Additional Requirements  
• Background check required before teaching.  
• Commitment to safeguarding policies and professional conduct standards.

Job Title: Online Coding Instructor (Youth Technology Education)

Company Overview:
We are an education‑technology organization dedicated to helping students ages 5 to 18 develop future‑ready skills in coding, computational thinking, and digital creativity. Our mission is to make high‑quality STEM education accessible worldwide through engaging, project‑based online learning.

Position Type:
Part‑time contract position with flexible scheduling. Instructors teach live online sessions and may work across global time zones based on availability and demand.

Role Summary:
The Online Coding Instructor delivers interactive, high‑quality virtual coding sessions for students at beginner, intermediate, and early advanced levels. The role focuses on teaching foundational programming concepts, guiding hands‑on projects, and ensuring a positive and safe online learning environment. Instructors collaborate with academic teams to follow structured curriculum materials and adapt lessons to different age groups.

Key Responsibilities:
• Teach block‑based and introductory programming concepts using Scratch, Blockly, or MIT App Inventor.  
• Teach beginner to intermediate text‑based programming with Python or JavaScript. (Note: instructors are not required to teach every language listed; assignments are based on skill alignment.)  
• Deliver structured lessons and guide students through curriculum‑aligned projects in areas such as app development, web development, game development, and early STEM robotics.  
• Introduce age‑appropriate concepts in AI literacy and computational thinking using provided curriculum materials.  
• Use interactive teaching methods including storytelling, real‑world examples, and project‑based exploration.  
• Adapt teaching style to meet the developmental and learning needs of students in different age groups.  
• Track learner progress through class reports, assessments, and individual feedback.  
• Provide constructive, encouraging feedback and personalize learning paths when appropriate.  
• Communicate professionally with parents and academic mentors to ensure learning goals are met.  
• Maintain a safe, respectful, and engaging online classroom environment.  
• Attend periodic training, calibration sessions, or instructor development workshops.

Required Qualifications:
• Bachelor’s degree in Computer Science, Engineering, Education, or a related field, or equivalent practical experience.  
• Minimum one year of experience teaching, tutoring, mentoring, or leading workshops for children or teens.  
• Strong programming fundamentals in at least one text‑based language such as Python or JavaScript.  
• Familiarity with block‑based tools like Scratch or similar platforms.  
• Excellent verbal communication skills and comfort teaching in a live online setting.  
• Ability to guide students patiently, manage virtual classroom dynamics, and simplify complex concepts.

Preferred Qualifications:
• Experience teaching coding or STEM subjects in an online environment.  
• Knowledge of beginner robotics platforms (micro:bit, LEGO, Arduino basics).  
• Background in youth engagement, coaching, or digital arts.  
• Certifications in teaching, computer science, or child safety compliance.

Technical Requirements:
• Reliable high‑speed internet connection.  
• Laptop or desktop computer with webcam, microphone, and updated browser.  
• Ability to use online teaching tools such as Zoom, Google Classroom, or proprietary learning platforms.

Work Schedule:
• Flexible scheduling with availability during evenings and weekends preferred.  
• Instructors choose preferred time zones but must maintain consistent weekly availability.

Reporting Structure:
• Reports to the Lead Instructor or Academic Coordinator.

Safety and Compliance:
• All candidates must pass a background check and adhere to child‑safety and data‑privacy policies.

Compensation:
• Competitive hourly rate based on experience, certifications, and technical skills. Additional incentives may be offered for high performance or advanced qualifications.

What Success Looks Like:
• Engaged students who complete projects and show measurable progress.  
• Clear communication with families and internal teams.  
• Consistent, reliable class delivery.  
• A creative, energetic teaching style that inspires confidence and curiosity in young learners.

Here are all issues found in the job description, grouped for clarity.

Redundancies and Repetition  
• The job description mixes two different roles: a coding teacher for children and a technical trainer responsible for placement and retention metrics.  
• Responsibilities repeat expectations about training, upgrading skills, and using online tools.  
• “Ability to train trainers” and “Ability to conduct TTT program online” are listed separately despite overlapping.  

Structural and Formatting Issues  
• The description abruptly shifts from “What we offer” to “Role Objective” without a clear section break.  
• The role objective is a single long run‑on sentence with multiple unrelated targets.  
• Responsibilities are listed in a continuous paragraph without clear formatting.  
• Lack of a job title—readers cannot tell what position this is.  

Content and Clarity Issues  
• Requirements imply both K‑12 coding instruction and adult professional/placement training, creating conflicting expectations.  
• “US Accent Certified” is unclear—no such standard certification exists; also may raise legal concerns in some regions.  
• “Strong command of block‑based and text‑based programming” is vague and should specify languages/platforms.  
• “Expertise in at least 3 domains…” is unrealistic when paired with 5+ years of teaching experience and all other requirements.  
• “Deep understanding of child & adolescent learning psychology” conflicts with placement‑driven adult‑training responsibilities.  
• “100% completion” and “100% training and placement targets” are unrealistic performance metrics.  
• “Maintain high trainer utilization” is ambiguous and appears managerial rather than instructional.  
• Placement‑related responsibilities (nomination‑to‑interview ratios, liaising with placement teams) are not aligned with coding educator roles.  
• “Drive day long online training sessions” is unclear—should specify hours and expectations.  
• Some items say “at least intermediate proficiency” even though the overall role seems senior.  

Compliance & Risk Issues  
• Accent‑based hiring can be discriminatory depending on jurisdiction.  
• Mix of child‑focused teaching and adult‑training/placement responsibilities may require different certifications (not addressed).  

Missing or Incomplete Elements  
• No mention of employment type, location expectations, work hours, or reporting structure.  
• Compensation details are vague.  
• No required degree or certification beyond the unclear accent requirement.  
• No background check requirement despite working with minors.

Job Title: Technical Trainer – Coding & Emerging Technologies  
Location: Remote

Overview  
We are looking for an experienced and passionate Technical Trainer who can deliver high-quality coding and technology education to school and college-level learners. The ideal candidate brings strong technical expertise, exceptional communication skills, and a genuine passion for inspiring young minds. In this role, you will design, deliver, and manage training programs, ensure impactful learning outcomes, and contribute to student success and placement readiness.

Key Qualifications  
• Certified US Accent, with the ability to communicate clearly, confidently, and engagingly.  
• Minimum 5 years of experience teaching programming or technology subjects to school or college students.  
• Strong proficiency in both block‑based and text‑based programming environments.  
• Expertise in at least three of the following areas:  
  – App Development  
  – Web Development  
  – Game Development  
  – Software Development  
  – Artificial Intelligence  
  – Robotics  
• Familiarity with major educational and coding platforms such as Zoom, Google Classroom, Scratch, and Replit.  
• Understanding of child and adolescent learning principles.  
• Excellent communication, storytelling, and learner‑engagement skills.  
• A passion for teaching, mentorship, and fostering innovation among young learners.

Role Objective  
To plan, deliver, and manage high‑impact technical training programs aligned with project goals, ensuring full training completion, high student engagement, strong placement outcomes, and continuous improvement in both instructional quality and domain expertise.

Core Responsibilities  
• Deliver structured training programs in line with project requirements, ensuring 100 percent completion of assigned learning modules.  
• Monitor attendance and proactively reduce dropout rates through consistent engagement, follow‑up, and learner support.  
• Provide academic mentoring, resolve technical queries, and offer career guidance to students.  
• Maintain attendance and engagement metrics as per organizational standards.  
• Continuously upgrade personal technical knowledge to keep pace with industry trends and emerging tools.  
• Support placement initiatives by preparing students for interviews, tracking progress, and coordinating with placement teams.  
• Guide learners in completing industry‑relevant projects aligned with curriculum goals.  
• Maintain high trainer utilization by effectively scheduling and delivering sessions.  
• Participate in upskilling programs, certifications, and internal training workshops.  
• Train and mentor other trainers or teachers as part of Train‑the‑Trainer (TTT) programs, including conducting TTT sessions online.  
• Use online teaching platforms such as Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, WebEx, or Skype, with proficiency in advanced features like breakout rooms, polls, and whiteboards.  
• Deliver full‑day online training sessions comfortably and effectively.

What We Offer  
• Opportunity to teach and inspire students globally.  
• Remote‑first, flexible work environment.  
• Competitive compensation based on experience and technical expertise.  
• Access to innovative curriculum, tools, teaching resources, and ongoing training.  
• The chance to be part of a purpose-driven edtech community shaping the future of learning.

General consistency issues
- The role mixes two very different profiles: a traditional Java/Python technical trainer and an advanced AI/LLM engineer‑trainer. The requirements contradict each other and create confusion about the actual job.

Content clarity issues
- Sentence: “Master’s degree in a relevant field (e.g., Engineering, Computer Science, ), well experienced Technical Trainer…” has a trailing comma and incomplete parenthetical.
- “Some one” should be “Someone.”
- “Hyderbad” should be “Hyderabad.”
- “TTT programme” appears twice but is not expanded (Train-the-Trainer?) and inconsistent in spelling (programme vs programs).
- Location requirement placement feels abrupt and not integrated into a section.

Redundancy and overlap
- Education requirements duplicate degrees in two different places.
- Java and Python trainer expertise appears, but later sections emphasize AI, LLMs, LangChain, RLHF, etc., creating overlap but unclear priority.
- Online training experience is mentioned twice in different forms.
- Certifications listed in multiple sections.

Unrealistic or mismatched expectations
- Requiring both deep experience in RLHF, LLM fine‑tuning, LangChain, and vector databases AND expecting them to also be a Java/Python general trainer is not realistic.
- Requiring only 2-3 years of experience yet expecting advanced AI/ML, LLM, and production deployment expertise is inconsistent with typical industry skill development timelines.
- “Experience in student placements” is typically for academic or campus trainer roles, conflicting with senior AI engineering expectations.

Structural issues
- No clear role responsibilities are described; only requirements are provided.
- Sections appear in an illogical order and mix unrelated topics.
- “Nice‑to‑Have” items include significantly advanced capabilities that should likely be core requirements if this is an AI/LLM trainer role.
- Lack of clarity on whether the job is an engineering role, a trainer role, a placement support role, or all three.

Missing details
- No details on job responsibilities, KPIs, reporting structure, or deliverables.
- No information about the employer, domain, or team.
- No work mode (onsite/hybrid) besides vague “willing to travel.”
- No compensation range, seniority level, or expected work hours.

Ambiguous or vague statements
- “Well experienced Technical Trainer in Java, Python” does not specify experience level or context.
- “Experience with agent frameworks” is vague; needs specificity.
- “Exposure to corporate training will be an advantage” provides no threshold.
- “Work from Hyderabad, Chennai or Bangalore” does not specify whether relocation is required.

Job Title: Technical Trainer – Software Engineering and Applied AI

Overview  
We are seeking a skilled Technical Trainer who can design and deliver high‑quality training programs in software development and applied AI technologies. The role involves conducting Train‑the‑Trainer (TTT) programs, delivering online and in‑person sessions, and supporting learners through structured curricula, hands‑on labs, and assessments. The ideal candidate combines strong programming expertise with the ability to explain complex concepts clearly and effectively.

Key Responsibilities  
• Deliver instructor‑led training (online and classroom) on Java, Python, and foundational to advanced AI/LLM concepts.  
• Conduct Train‑the‑Trainer (TTT) programs to upskill trainers and ensure consistent delivery quality.  
• Develop and update training content, modules, labs, and assessments aligned with industry standards.  
• Use online meeting and learning‑management platforms effectively to deliver engaging sessions.  
• Provide mentorship and technical guidance to learners; collaborate with placement or career‑development teams when needed.  
• Support the deployment of hands‑on projects, including AI/LLM prototypes, coding assignments, and capstone work.  
• Stay updated on emerging technologies and integrate relevant tools and frameworks into the curriculum.  
• Travel occasionally to training sites as required.

Required Qualifications  
• Bachelor’s or Master’s degree in Computer Science, Engineering, Data Science, AI, or a related field.  
• Strong coding experience in Java and Python.  
• Minimum 2–3 years of experience delivering technical training or TTT programs.  
• Experience conducting online training sessions using modern conferencing and collaboration tools.  
• Proven ability to simplify complex concepts for diverse learner groups.  
• Excellent communication, presentation, and facilitation skills.

Technical Skills  
• Solid understanding of modern AI concepts, including Transformer models, LLMs, fine‑tuning, and RLHF.  
• Strong hands‑on programming skills in Python and familiarity with Jupyter environments.  
• Experience with frameworks such as PyTorch, TensorFlow, LangChain, AutoGPT, and Hugging Face Transformers.  
• Working knowledge of vector databases such as Pinecone, FAISS, or Weaviate.  
• Experience designing Retrieval‑Augmented Generation (RAG) pipelines and building LLM‑based applications.  
• Familiarity with agent frameworks (e.g., LangChain agents, ReAct‑style agents).  
• Awareness of AI safety, ethics, and responsible AI deployment practices.

Preferred Qualifications  
• Certification in Train‑the‑Trainer programs.  
• Certifications in AI/ML such as Google Cloud ML, Azure AI, or DeepLearning.ai GenAI specialization.
